definitions.definition: the things that are contained in something

examples.text: He tipped the contents of the bag onto the table.
Fire has caused severe damage to the contents of the building.
She hadn't read the letter and so was unaware of its contents.
She picked up the glass and drank the contents.

definitions.definition: the different sections that are contained in a book

examples.text: a **table of contents** *(= the list at the front of a book)*
a contents page

definitions.definition: the subject matter of a book, speech, programme, etc.

examples.text: Her poetry has a good deal of political content.
Your tone of voice is as important as the content of what you have to say.
The content of the course depends on what the students would like to study.
This study is based on a content analysis of press coverage of the president during his time in office.

definitions.definition: the amount of a substance that is contained in something else

examples.text: food with a high **fat content**
**water/moisture/protein/DNA content**
the alcohol content of a drink

definitions.definition: the information or other material contained on a website or other digital media

examples.text: **digital/video/online content**
We plan to spend more on **creating content** for the website.
**delivering** premium **content** to users
a method of **sharing content** over the internet
to **stream/access/consume/view content**
**content management**
The way people are accessing their Web content is changing.
They haven't updated the content of their site.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from medieval Latin contentum (plural contenta ‘things contained’), neuter past participle of continere from con- ‘altogether’ + tenere ‘to hold’.
